results.title: Filming Miss Fisher at the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Tim Entwisle, Director and CEO of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne, introduces the history of the Gardens and Observatory buildings, discussing their initial development in the ‘Marvellous Melbourne’ of the gold rush, and their place in Melbourne’s social and intellectual life.
Tim also recounts the story of the infamous serial killings that took place in the Gardens in the 1920s.

results.title: Film: the art of the impossible
results.brief_description: Film director Michael Ritchie analyses selected sequences from well known films and demonstrates some of the devices used to make scenes realistic and to create drama. Includes the use of the camera, sound, lighting, script, casting choices and direction of actors, sets, costumes and music.

results.title: Film: a tool for teachers
results.brief_description: This film, designed primarily for teachers in training, has been compiled to demonstrate the possibilities of film as a teaching tool. It consists of excerpts from 18 films, selected because they illustrate the properties peculiar to film for communicating information and ideas. The excerpts are arranged in four groups which illustrate the contribution film can make to four kinds of educational situation: demonstrating practical skills; providing a visual description; organising knowledge and stimulating the imagination.

results.title: Film workshop
results.creator_credit: J B Parsons and Associates and J Parsons
results.brief_description: This film shows the production of two short films by third-year boys at Cornwell Secondary Modern School, East Hampshire. At this school a complete four year syllabus was devised so thet every boy received at least an hour’s screen education each week.

results.title: Film technique: editing. Parts 1 and 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Explains the editor’s responsibilities and summarises the various stages of editing. The first part deals mainly with the editing of silent films. The second part is more complex and discusses the editing of film with sound and synchronising sound and picture. Intended for film and TV trainees and technical colleges.

results.brief_description: A vivid and humorous presentation of how to use sound films to the best effect, and the various results of different kinds of failures on the part of the instructor using a sound film.

results.title: Film strips and splicers
results.brief_description: With transparent, flexible, plastic strips coated with light sensitive gelatine emulsions, film strips were used to capture light and create pictures.
results.description: Before advancements in digital technology made the editing process easier, editors spliced and arranged film strips and frames to tell cohesive stories and represent the director’s vision. Splicers aren’t only used to join lengths of photographic film though, they’re also used to create cuts and transitions, or repair damaged films. They come in a variety of shapes depending on the film stock used, whether that’s Super 8 or 70mm. Tape splicers can be used on most film types and are commonly found in cinemas, where they’re used to join polyester prints. Cement splicers can only be used with acetate, triacetate and nitrate films are they need the film’s emulsion to help bind two lengths with a chemical called film cement.
description_for_label: Before advancements in digital technology made the editing process easier, editors spliced and arranged film strips and frames to tell cohesive stories and represent the director’s vision. Splicers aren’t only used to join lengths of photographic film though, they’re also used to create cuts and transitions, or repair damaged films. They come in a variety of shapes depending on the film stock used, whether that’s Super 8 or 70mm. Tape splicers can be used on most film types and are commonly found in cinemas, where they’re used to join polyester prints. Cement splicers can only be used with acetate, triacetate and nitrate films are they need the film’s emulsion to help bind two lengths with a chemical called film cement.

results.title: Film strips
results.brief_description: What are the most commonly used film guages? 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.

constellations_primary.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_primary.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

results.description:
What explodes like gunpowder and made movies possible? Celluloid.

British American photographer John Carbutt developed celluloid sheets for photographic plates around 1888. They were used in cylindrical Kinetographs, but they were too stiff for motion-picture cameras. Enter Hannibal Goodwin and Kodak founder George Eastman, two New Yorkers who independently created flexible film from highly combustible nitrocellulose, which could sometimes explode in projectors! The two inventors raced each other to patent their technology, but Eastman received his patent first and began mass-producing film for Thomas Edison.

These strips are the most commonly used film gauges: 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.
description_for_label:
What explodes like gunpowder and made movies possible? Celluloid.

British American photographer John Carbutt developed celluloid sheets for photographic plates around 1888. They were used in cylindrical Kinetographs, but they were too stiff for motion-picture cameras. Enter Hannibal Goodwin and Kodak founder George Eastman, two New Yorkers who independently created flexible film from highly combustible nitrocellulose, which could sometimes explode in projectors! The two inventors raced each other to patent their technology, but Eastman received his patent first and began mass-producing film for Thomas Edison.

These strips are the most commonly used film gauges: 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.
